title: Control of impulsive action
descriptions: The proposed project, "Control of impulsive action," aims to advance our understanding of impulse-control mechanisms and their potential for societal benefit. The research will address key questions such as the emergence of novel impulsive actions during task preparation, the influence of negative emotions on impulsive behavior, and the role of learning in modulating impulsivity. Utilizing a combination of behavioral paradigms, cognitive neuroscience techniques (TMS & EEG), physiological measures (facial EMG), and mathematical modeling of decision-making, the project seeks to achieve several objectives. These include specifying the origin and control of impulsive actions, replacing current inhibitory control models with multifaceted models, explaining impulsivity across time and space, developing a new behavioral model of impulsive action, understanding individual differences in impulsivity, and exploring disorders associated with impulse-control deficits. By addressing these objectives, the research aims to provide valuable insights into impulsive behavior and pave the way for interventions to improve impulse control in individuals, ultimately benefiting both individuals and society as a whole.
